title: 114_s1996
content: The "Commonsense Reporting Act of 2015" aims to minimize compliance burdens on businesses, insurance carriers, and individuals by implementing methods to strike a balance between reporting for law enforcement and protecting privacy. It also establishes a voluntary prospective reporting system. The "Commonsense Reporting Act of 2015" mandates the development of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Secretary of the Treasury within a year of enactment. Employers can voluntarily report information before the annual open enrollment period under the Affordable Care Act. The "Commonsense Reporting Act of 2015" requires employers to report on whether they offer minimum essential coverage to full-time and part-time employees, dependents, and spouses. The "Commonsense Reporting Act of 2015" mandates employers to report on the availability of coverage that meets minimum value requirements, affordability safe harbors, and potential shared responsibility payments under section 4980H of the Internal Revenue Code. Additionally, they must specify the months during the reporting period when such coverage is accessible to eligible individuals. The "Commonsense Reporting Act of 2015" requires employers to report on coverage availability, waiting periods, and access to information for eligibility determinations of premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act. Processes are outlined for secure access to information by Exchanges, the Data Services Hub, and the IRS. The "Commonsense Reporting Act of 2015" outlines processes for Exchanges to obtain necessary information from employers regarding employee eligibility for advance payments and cost-sharing subsidies. It also includes a process for employers to update the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub on any changes in coverage for participating employees. The "Commonsense Reporting Act of 2015" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by specifying reporting requirements for employers regarding employee enrollment in qualified health plans. It exempts certain reporting requirements under the Code and outlines procedures for updating coverage changes for participating employees. The "Commonsense Reporting Act of 2015" adds a new subsection (f) exempting employers who provide prospective reporting through the system created under the Act from certain return and statement requirements for the calendar year. This includes furnishing statements to employees enrolled in qualified health plans. The "Commonsense Reporting Act of 2015" allows employers to contract with a third party for reporting without affecting their compliance with return requirements. Additionally, it grants access to the National Directory of New Hires for the Secretaries of Treasury and Health and Human Services. Services will have access to the National Directory of New Hires for administering specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code and the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide guidance for employees to request their employer's identification number. Congress supports funding for a voluntary prospective reporting system. Congress supports appropriations to various government agencies for building and maintaining a voluntary prospective reporting system. Protection of dependent privacy is emphasized in Section 4. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow the use of an individual's full name and date of birth in place of their TIN if the health insurance issuer or employer is unable to collect or maintain TIN information. The Social Security Administration will assist the IRS in providing data matches to determine the TIN associated with the provided name and date of birth. The amendment allows the use of an individual's full name and date of birth instead of their TIN if necessary. The effective date for this change is 60 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. ELECTRONIC STATEMENTS. SEC. 5. ELECTRONIC STATEMENTS. (a) In General.--Subsection (c) of section 6056 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow individuals to consent to receive statements electronically from their employer. (b) Statements Relating to Health Insurance Coverage.--Subsection (c) of section 6055 is also amended to allow electronic delivery of statements. The amendments made by this section allow individuals to consent to receive statements electronically from their employer. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2015. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating the prospective reporting system established under section 3 of the Act. The study will assess the accuracy of information collected, the number of employers using the system, and any challenges faced. Results will be reported to specific Senate and House committees.
